author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
MIT 18.156 Projection Theory, Spring 2025
Instructor: Lawrence D Guth
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-156-projection-theory-spring-2025
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP62K9_7Pg26ytrAOXwXFpN43

We introduce two fundamental methods to study projections, developed by Kaufman and Falconer in the 1960s and 70s. The first is based on double counting. The second is based on Fourier analysis.

License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA
More information at https://ocw.mit.edu/terms
More courses at https://ocw.mit.edu
Support OCW at http://ow.ly/a1If50zVRlQ

We encourage constructive comments and discussion on OCW’s YouTube and other social media channels. Personal attacks, hate speech, trolling, and inappropriate comments are not allowed and may be removed. More details at https://ocw.mit.edu/comments.
title: Lecture 02: Fundamental Methods of Projection Theory

author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
MIT 18.156 Projection Theory, Spring 2025
Instructor: Lawrence D Guth
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-156-projection-theory-spring-2025
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP62K9_7Pg26ytrAOXwXFpN43

We discuss the analogy between the Szemeredi-Trotter theorem and the exceptional set problem. We explain why it is hard to adapt the proof of Szemeredi-Trotter to the exceptional set problem.

author: MIT OpenCourseWare
description:
MIT 18.156 Projection Theory, Spring 2025
Instructor: Lawrence D Guth
View the complete course: https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/18-156-projection-theory-spring-2025
YouTube Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUl4u3cNGP62K9_7Pg26ytrAOXwXFpN43

We begin studying the recent breakthrough in projection theory by Orponen-Shmerkin and Ren-Wang. We discuss how to use a non-sharp bound many times to get a sharp bound.
